questions.question: By next week, I _____ my new bike.
questions.explanation: We use 'will have' + past participle (ridden) to show that the action of riding the new bike will be completed by next week.

questions.question: "The cat will have caught three mice by midnight" is in future perfect tense.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'will have' + past participle (caught) to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time (midnight).

questions.question: Which sentence is in future perfect tense?

options.text: We will plant a tree tomorrow.
We will be planting a tree tomorrow.
We will have planted a tree by Earth Day.
We planted a tree last year.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (planted) to show that the tree planting will be finished before a future event (Earth Day).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: By the time school starts, Jenny _____ (learn) to tie her shoes.
questions.explanation: We use 'will have learned' to indicate that Jenny will finish learning to tie her shoes before the future event of school starts.

questions.question: Choose the correct future perfect tense sentence:

options.text: The painter will paint the house next month.
The painter will be painting the house next month.
The painter will have painted the house by next month.
The painter painted the house last year.

questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'will have' + past participle (painted) to show that the painting will be completed by a specific future time (next month).

questions.question: Future perfect tense always uses 'will have' + present participle of the verb.
questions.explanation: Future perfect tense uses 'will have' + past participle of the verb, not the present participle form.

questions.question: By the time I go to bed, I _____ my homework.
questions.explanation: We use 'will have' + past participle (finished) to show that the homework will be completed before the future event of going to bed.

questions.question: Which sentence uses future perfect tense correctly?

options.text: The bus will arrive at 3 PM.
The bus will be arriving at 3 PM.
The bus will have arrived by 3 PM.
The bus will have arriving at 3 PM yesterday.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (arrived) to indicate that the bus's arrival will be completed by a specific future time (3 PM).

questions.question: Identify the future perfect tense sentence:

options.text: The snow will melt in spring.
The snow will have melted by summer.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (melted) to show that the snow's melting will be completed before a future time (summer).

questions.question: "They will have travelled to five countries by the end of the year" is in the future perfect tense.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'will have' + past participle (travelled) to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time (the end of the year).

questions.question: Which sentence is in future perfect tense?

options.text: The baby will have crawled by her first birthday.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (crawled) to indicate that the baby will achieve crawling before a future event (her first birthday).

questions.question: Choose the correct future perfect tense sentence:

options.text: The chef will cook dinner at 6 PM.
The chef will be cooking dinner at 6 PM.
The chef will have cooked dinner by 6 PM.
The chef cooked will have dinner yesterday.

questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'will have' + past participle (cooked) to show that the cooking will be completed by a specific future time (6 PM).

questions.question: The future perfect tense is used to talk about actions that will be ongoing in the future.
questions.explanation: The future perfect tense is used for actions that will be completed by a certain point in the future, not for ongoing actions.

questions.question: By the time we reach the top of the mountain, we _____ for three hours.
questions.explanation: We use 'will have' + past participle (climbed) to show that the climbing will have been ongoing for three hours when we reach the top.

questions.question: Which sentence uses future perfect tense?

options.text: The leaves will change colour in autumn.
The leaves are changing colour now.
The leaves will have changed colour by winter.
The leaves changed colour last fall.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (changed) to indicate that the leaves colour change will be completed before a future time (winter).

questions.question: "She will have practising the piano for two hours by dinnertime" is in the future perfect tense.
questions.explanation: The sentence uses the incorrect form of the verb. The sentence should use 'will have' + past participle (practised) to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time (dinnertime).

questions.question: Which sentence is in future perfect tense?

options.text: The sun will set at 8 PM.
The sun will have set by the time we finish dinner.
The sun set an hour ago.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (set) to indicate that the sunset will be completed before another future event (finishing dinner).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: By next month, the library _____ (add) 100 new books.
questions.explanation: We use 'will have added' to show that the library will finish adding 100 new books by the time next month arrives.

questions.question: In future perfect tense, we always use 'will have' followed by a verb ending in '-ing'.
questions.explanation: In future perfect tense, we use 'will have' followed by the past participle of the verb, not the '-ing' form.

questions.question: Which sentence uses future perfect tense correctly?

options.text: The train will leave the station at noon.
The train will be leaving the station at noon.
The train will have left the station by 12:15 PM.
The train left the station yesterday.

questions.explanation: This sentence uses 'will have' + past participle (left) to indicate that the train's departure will be completed by a specific future time (12:15 PM).
